7/ Everyone I met was sincere and I do think there is a genuine desire of many of these innovators to do good.

But today, it feels like we work for technology, instead of technology working for us. This needs to change. Fast.

6/ Finally, it's clear that there is still no way for the social media companies to police themselves into responsible behavior. The algorithms are too opaque, the platforms are too intentionally addictive, the protections for kids are too weak.

5/ Also a lack of acknowledgement here that the last 25 years of technological change has been uniquely dislocating. For instance, EVERY SINGLE leader I met w compared social media to the printing press, arguing that every big new technology is met with early na√Øve skepticism.

4/ What I found in my meetings is a view of innovation and increased connectivity as a near universal net good. Feels like a bit of a innovation hamster wheel. Not enough leaders seriously asking - does the innovation actually increase citizens' happiness?

3/ But for many, tech now overwhelms and vexes us, addicting our children to screens, funneling users into information silos, elevating the most extreme voices, and consolidating power and wealth into the select expert elites who know how manipulate the technology.

2/ I feel from my constituents an increasingly distrust of and exhaustion with technology. Technology promised to make our lives easier, help us build more fulfilling personal connections, and give us access to new economic opportunities.

Finishing a trip to San Fran/Silicon Valley. Met with many smart and thoughtful tech leaders.

But there's still a big disconnect between how average Americans think about technology vs. how the industry views tech. It's a dangerous divide.

I‚Äôm proud this amazing innovation came from our humble slice of NJ. I‚Äôm grateful to the @RoeblingMuseum for keeping this history alive. It‚Äôs a story of American determination that makes us stop and appreciate some of the things we take for granted. END http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdCIjwwWQAEBwaI.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdCIjw2XwAA48yC.jpg

Roebling wire rope was used to hold together the first Wright brothers plane. The elevators of the Eiffel Tower (and inspired nearly every other elevator). The cable cars of San Francisco. The control cable of the Spirit of St Louis. 7/8 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdCIjaqX0AAKb0a.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdCIjatXgAQgoP5.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdCIjapXkAMlXU2.jpg

Roeblings created a factory town in Burlington county NJ that made 88K miles of Roebling wire that still holds up Golden Gate Bridge. Their wire holds up George Washington Bridge (busiest bridge in the world) and design now used for nearly every suspension bridge in the world.6/8 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdCIjF2XEAE_2Jc.jpg

The process cost him his life and his son Washington and daughter in law Emily took over. And in 1883 (14 yrs later) the Roebling family were the first to cross the bridge for what was the longest suspension bridge in the world.5/8 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdCIil5X0AMd_LG.jpg

But the holy grail was the East River. Back then, Manhattan and Brooklyn were basically two separate cities, connected only by ferries that couldn‚Äôt cross when the river would freeze during the winters. Roebling proposed building a bridge unlike anything ever seen before.4/8 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdCIiSiXoAAbWW1.jpg

Roebling immediately started envisioning how wire rope could transform suspension bridges, which at that time was done with chain-link instead. Roebling built the very first suspension wire bridges in the world including this one named after him still standing in Cincinnati. 3/8 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdCIh-6WIAIHG8d.jpg

I stopped at the museum in town of Roebling. They told me the story of how John Roebling was working the NY canals back in mid 1800s and saw boats pulled by hemp rope that kept breaking. The bill would eliminate the congressional review period for DC legislation. Currently, DC legislation takes effect after a review period, unless a resolution of disapproval is enacted.

The bill would give DC the authority to grant clemency for DC crimes. Currently, the president exercises the authority to grant clemency for DC crimes‚Äîand almost never uses it.

DC should decide whether DC residents deserve mercy. (3/5)

The bill would give DC the authority to prosecute all DC crimes. Currently, the US Attorney for DC prosecutes most DC crimes committed by adults and some by juveniles.

The prosecutor of DC crimes should be accountable to DC, not to the president. (2/5)

While opening the new VA clinic in Ventura County has been my highest priority, I believe that naming the clinic after Captain Rosemary Bryant Mariner provides us with yet another opportunity to recognize the service and sacrifice of women veterans. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdDjBCtXwAAt5K9.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdDjBzrXgAEafVR.jpg
Captain Mariner was a true pioneer for women in the military, and she was the true embodiment of the American Spirit. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdDi-F7XkAAeMgc.jpg

Captain Mariner was named commander of Navy Tactical Electronic Warfare Squadron 34 at Naval Air Station Point Mugu. The unit was 30 percent female and made Captain Mariner the first woman to command an operational air squadron. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdDi8YZXgAI2f04.jpg

Captain Mariner, a former resident of Ventura County, joined the Navy in 1973 where she became a member of the Navy‚Äôs first flight-training class for women. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdDi66DXoAMo4uY.jpg
After receiving recommendations from the community, the advisory panel chose to name the new clinic after Captain Rosemary Bryant Mariner. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdDi5btWQAUh_8U.jpg
To address this issue, I convened a local citizen advisory panel, comprised of veterans and community leaders to select a woman veteran for whom we could name the new VA clinic in Ventura.

In fact, of the 1,255 VA healthcare facilities, only two facilities have been named in honor of women veterans. Because so few veteran facilities are named after women, we are reminded of the inequity women veterans face.
Through my work as Chair of the #WomenVetsTaskForce, I am constantly reminded that women are the most visible while serving, and the most invisible when they return to civilian life.
Today, the House passed my bill to name the new VA clinic in Ventura after Captain Rosemary Bryant Mariner. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdDi4PjX0AEnR3v.jpg
